meanings.definition: To use irony in speech or writing.
meanings.sent1: She would often ironise her comments to make them more interesting.
meanings.sent2: The author liked to ironise serious topics in his novels.
meanings.sent3: During the play, the character would ironise situations to add humor.
meanings.sent4: Her tone would ironise the gravity of the situation, making it seem lighter.
meanings.sent5: The comedian's jokes always ironise common stereotypes.

meanings.definition: To convey a meaning opposite to the literal sense.
meanings.sent1: His words seemed to ironise his true feelings on the matter.
meanings.sent2: The movie's title was meant to ironise the storyline.
meanings.sent3: The politician's speech would often ironise his opponent's arguments.
meanings.sent4: The painting's colors seemed to ironise the artist's emotions.
meanings.sent5: The song's lyrics cleverly ironise the upbeat melody.
